image.altText: Photograph outside the Australian Tax Office headquarters

items.synopsis: Following an ABC Investigation, the Australian Tax Office admits criminals have fraudulently claimed more than $557 million from the Commonwealth using an identity loophole.

title.children: ATO admits identity loophole exposed by the ABC tops half a billion dollars

image.altText: Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis side-by-side with his brain scan

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: The effect of decades of head knocks isn't immediately obvious on Gordi. That is, until you see his brain

image.altText: A woman in a two-tone denim jacket, stands at her kitchen bench.

items.synopsis: One in 25 Australians have lodged an insurance claim because of extreme weather since 2020, but should the remaining policyholders be responsible for sharing the cost of increased premiums?

title.children: Rachel's home insurance payments increased by $840 this year. She's just one Australian sharing the cost of more claims

image.altText: A woman with dark hair pulled into a bun smiles, standing in front of a floor to ceiling book shelf.

items.synopsis: Kamilaroi woman Louise Taylor will be appointed the first Indigenous female Supreme Court judge today. It is the second time she has made history, after she was appointed as the ACT's first Indigenous magistrate in 2018.

title.children: Louise Taylor will become Australia's first female Indigenous Supreme Court judge. It's not the first time she's made history

image.altText: Geoff and Rhonda doing a puzzle.

items.synopsis: Geoff is selectively mute and has a fragile X syndrome. When his mother engaged a disability service to take him to work, she didn't know it would use up almost all his NDIS funding.

title.children: Geoff was driven to work three days a week. He received a $700 invoice for it

image.altText: A red up arrow next to a percentage sign on top of an aerial view of dozens of houses.

items.synopsis: The level of mortgage arrears is creeping higher and the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress is at its highest level since 2008.

title.children: Mortgage arrears rising as 'at risk' borrowers hit pre-GFC peaks

image.altText: A family sits around and reads a book.

items.synopsis: This Dolly Parton program sends children a free book every month until they turn five. Results show these kids are being read to far more often than the average Australian child.

title.children: This city signed up newborns to a reading program created by Dolly Parton. These are the results

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

items.synopsis: Do you know your PP from your HDPE, and your PVC from your soft plastics? Plastic recycling is a minefield, so here's how to tell what you're dealing with and which bin you should put it in.

title.children: Plastic not so fantastic: Do you know which numbers can't be recycled?

image.altText: A woman with glasses wearing a high-vis vest stands in front of plastic waste piles.

items.synopsis: Liz Kasell, who founded the REDcycle soft plastic recycling scheme which collapsed with thousands of tonnes of plastic stockpiled in warehouses across the country, insists she believed materials being collected by the company would be saved from landfill.

title.children: REDcycle founder says she had 'no doubt' stockpiled plastic would be recycled

image.altText: A grand, multi-story English country home, made from stone, with pillars and grand windows, including a garden with hedges

items.synopsis: Britain is having a belated reckoning with its slave past — a past that is closely connected to rum.

title.children: 'A wicked, evil mindset': Behind many historic British buildings, there's a very uncomfortable truth

image.altText: A centrelink sign with on a building with a reflection

items.synopsis: Behavioural economics is a discipline that seems blind to empathy. The care with which Robodebt letters were designed — and the so-called science behind those devastating design decisions — showed what it could do, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Great care was taken over the design of Robodebt letters, right down to the colour. Here's why

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Economists predict rapid rate rises by the Reserve Bank will see a slow down in price rises over the June quarter, while the International Monetary Fund warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation pull-back predicted, IMF warns of economic challenges, US stocks rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I put this question to chief economist at Betashares, David Bassanese this morning ahead of the inflation figures dropping in just under an hour's time. He said the RBA's May statement on monetary policy showed the central bank was forecasting headline inflation falling to 6.25%, and trimmed mean inflation falling to 6% — which would represent a "substantial decline" from current rates. Inflation figures in that ballpark would be enough for them to hold off on raising interest rates at next week's meeting, he said. "I think you'd need to see at least that for them to hold off," Mr Bassanese said. " Anything higher, I think they'll raise rates, but I'm hopeful that we actually get numbers better than that, that inflation, both true mean and headline can actually drop to drop to maybe 5.8%, 5.9%, and that would be enough I think for them to hold off." But taking all things into account, Mr Bassanese still expects two more rate rises by the end of the year. "I've got two more rate rises to come. I actually think, end of the day, demand is going to remain," he said. "We've seen some softening in consumer spending, but I just think labour market and spending ... and in fact, a decline in inflation can sort of boost real incomes a little bit, so I think we're going to see some resilience in the consumer sector and the housing market seems to be bouncing back. "So I think the RBA is probably going to raise rates twice more by year end, but maybe hold off this month if the CPI is OK. "We'll see, but that's my view."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What inflation figure does the RBA want to see today?

children.content: I put this question to chief economist at Betashares,
David Bassanese
this morning ahead of the inflation figures dropping in just under an hour's time.

He said the RBA's May statement on monetary policy showed the central bank was forecasting headline inflation falling to 6.25%, and trimmed mean inflation falling to 6% — which would represent a "substantial decline" from current rates.
Inflation figures in that ballpark would be enough for them to hold off on raising interest rates at next week's meeting, he said.
"I think you'd need to see at least that for them to hold off," Mr Bassanese said.
Anything higher, I think they'll raise rates

, but I'm hopeful that we actually get numbers better than that, that inflation, both true mean and headline can actually drop to drop to maybe 5.8%, 5.9%, and that would be enough I think for them to hold off."
But taking all things into account, Mr Bassanese still expects two more rate rises by the end of the year.
"I've got
two more rate rises to come
. I actually think, end of the day, demand is going to remain," he said.
"We've seen some softening in consumer spending, but I just think labour market and spending ... and in fact, a decline in inflation can sort of boost real incomes a little bit, so
I think we're going to see some resilience in the consumer sector
and the housing market seems to be bouncing back.
"So I think the
RBA is probably going to raise rates twice more by year end
, but
maybe hold off this month if the CPI is OK
"We'll see, but that's my view."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have opened higher after stocks rose on Wall Street and as miners get another boost from China's promises of more stimulus. Most sectors are lower on the ASX 200, but miners are driving the gains. Here are the best and worst performers. Beach Energy: +3.9 per cent Champion Iron: +3.7 per cent Perseus Mining: +2.6 per cent Qantas: -2.7% Telix Pharmaceuticals: -1.8% Breville: -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market rises in early trade

children.content: Australian shares have opened higher after stocks rose on Wall Street and as miners get another boost from China's promises of more stimulus.
Most sectors are lower on the ASX 200, but miners are driving the gains.
Here are the best and worst performers.
Beach Energy: +3.9 per cent
Champion Iron: +3.7 per cent
Perseus Mining: +2.6 per cent
Qantas: -2.7%
Telix Pharmaceuticals: -1.8%
Breville: -1.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank watches core inflation more closely than the headline Consumer Price Index as an indication of where prices are going. Core or underlying inflation strips out volatile items like fruit, vegetables and petrol. While headline prices are coming down, core inflation came in at 6.4 per cent over the year to May according to the Bureau of Statistics. That was a tiny decline from the 6.5 per cent over the year to April. Core inflation remains high because of strong services inflation including rent and energy prices. The market is expecting one of the measures of core inflation, the Trimmed Mean CPI, to rise by 1.1 per cent over the June quarter and by 6 per cent over the year to June, which would be a pull back from the 6.6 per cent annual rate over the March quarter. National Australia Bank says that would be in line with the RBA's latest economic forecasts. However NAB's head of foreign exchange strategy Ray Attrill warns: "We are fearful that the underlying details on services dominated by wages, rent and energy - which we expect to show no signs of moderation - could reduce the RBA's confidence in CPI falling back to the top of the target band (3 per cent) in a reasonable time frame." "Hence we see the need for further RBA tightening, including next week if this is indeed the message from today's figures."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is core inflation?

children.content: The Reserve Bank watches core inflation more closely than the headline Consumer Price Index as an indication of where prices are going.
Core or underlying inflation strips out volatile items like fruit, vegetables and petrol.
While headline prices are coming down, core inflation came in at 6.4 per cent over the year to May according to the Bureau of Statistics.
That was a tiny decline from the 6.5 per cent over the year to April.

props.alt: Graph of consumer price index since May 2019

children.content: Core inflation
(ABS)
Core inflation remains high because of strong services inflation including rent and energy prices.

The market is expecting one of the measures of core inflation, the Trimmed Mean CPI, to rise by 1.1 per cent over the June quarter and by 6 per cent over the year to June, which would be a pull back from the 6.6 per cent annual rate over the March quarter.
National Australia Bank says that would be in line with the RBA's latest economic forecasts.
However NAB's head of foreign exchange strategy Ray Attrill warns:

"We are fearful that the underlying details on services dominated by wages, rent and energy - which we expect to show no signs of moderation - could reduce the RBA's confidence in CPI falling back to the top of the target band (3 per cent) in a reasonable time frame."
"Hence we see the need for further RBA tightening, including next week if this is indeed the message from today's figures."

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

items.synopsis: A Canberra man who admitted sexually abusing his young teenage daughter for more than two years is jailed after his daughter told the ACT Supreme Court he was a monster who had ruined her life.

title.children: Father who sexually abused his daughter 'became the monster' he was meant to protect her from, court hears

image.altText: A modern-looking building that reads "Hellenic" above the Greek-style entry.

items.synopsis: Three development applications for the Hellenic Club in Woden have been approved by the ACT's Environment, Planning and Sustainable Development Directorate, with construction scheduled to begin next year.

title.children: Hellenic Club receives approval for $146m redevelopment that includes hotel, restaurants, infinity pool

image.altText: A collation of photos of a football player.

items.synopsis: In 1999, just 90 seconds into her first Women's World Cup start, Alicia Ferguson-Cook made history — but for all the wrong reasons.

title.children: How one moment of madness changed the trajectory of a Matildas star's football career

image.altText: A man in a tuxedo and a woman in a formal black gown

title.children: How soccer's greatest star was lured to America by the Beckhams and a promise of many millions

image.altText: Greyhound legs and lower torso while the animal is running.

title.children: South Australian greyhounds captured on video apparently being kicked, punched

image.altText: A person lies on a couch with an eyemask and headphones on while a woman and man watch on.

items.synopsis: Australia has just legalised psilocybin and MDMA for treating depression and PTSD, but is the health profession ready?

title.children: Therapists try psychedelics for themselves, amid concern over mixed results for patients

image.altText: A Chinese man in a suit and glasses

items.synopsis: Qin Gang was seen as close to Chinese President Xi Jinping and became one of China's youngest foreign ministers last December, when he replaced the man who will now return to the job.

title.children: China replaces missing foreign minister with his predecessor

image.altText: Lebron James with his arm around his son who is holding a trophy and smiling

items.synopsis: Bronny James, the 18-year-old son of the NBA legend is recovering in hospital after the health scare during practice.

title.children: LeBron James's teen son in a stable condition after cardiac arrest

image.altText: Gina Rinehart at Roy Hill

items.synopsis: The claim the mining magnate knew her company's Hope Downs mines were part of a joint partnership are central to a high-profile dispute over unpaid royalties playing out in court.

title.children: Lawyers say 1986 letter proves Gina Rinehart knew lucrative iron ore mines were not just hers

image.altText: An elderly man with a white beard looks stern.

items.synopsis: Bunbury resident Bob Barber says he and his wife would be "starving" without food support from organisations like Doors Wide Open and Foodbank.

title.children: This grandfather worked his whole life. Now he can't afford to buy groceries

image.altText: a photo of a young woman looking at camera

items.synopsis: A Bendigo Pilates teacher is calling on social media companies to do more to protect users after falling victim to a "very smooth" scam that locked her out of her account — then used it to target other victims.

title.children: 'I am mortified': How Caroline's Instagram account was used to scam an elderly woman out of $2,000

image.altText: David Pass sits in the in Queensland Health's Forensic and Scientific Services lab, boxes of vapes stand nearby

items.synopsis: Impounded vapes are being tested for polonium-210, a radioisotope which naturally occurs in cigarette tobacco.

title.children: Scientists suspect vapes contain 'weapon of espionage' polonium-210 after finding cancer-causing substances

image.altText: cheynes beach stranding

items.synopsis: Dozens of pilot whales massed near Cheynes Beach, east of Albany, are becoming stranded on the shore.

title.children: Mass whale stranding underway off Western Australia's southern coast

image.altText: Two men in a tank.

items.synopsis: A ferocious battle is playing out inside the corporate boardrooms of Germany and South Korea, as a decision looms on a five-year-long tendering process for one of the Australian Army's most lucrative contracts on record.

title.children: Multi-billion-dollar decision looms for Australia to replace Vietnam War-era army vehicles

image.altText: New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins, left, listens as Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaks

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will jet into the Kiwi capital Wellington today for defence and economic talks with his New Zealand counterpart Chris Hipkins.

title.children: Albanese heads across the Tasman, with talks of domestic politics, defence and trade on the table

image.altText: Rescuers operate at the site where a firefighting plane crashed after a water drop as a wildfires burn in Greece.

items.synopsis: Footage broadcast on state television shows the plane dropping water over a fire and then crashing into a hillside and bursting into flames.

title.children: Plane fighting wildfires in Greece crashes killing two on board

image.altText: A person sits wearing black and looking serious while holding a report on a table.

items.synopsis: The survey, the first of its kind, shows nearly one in two young Indigenous LGBTIQA+ Australians have attempted suicide at some point in their life.

title.children: New report shines spotlight on 'shocking' rates of self-harm among young Indigenous LGBTIQA+ people

image.altText: a large aboriginal flag flying above a large group of people at a city march

items.synopsis: State and territory governments are not being held accountable for failing to meet Closing the Gap targets and in some cases are actively exacerbating disadvantage, a Productivity Commission report finds.

title.children: 'Another broken promise to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people': Report warns of continued disadvantage

image.altText: A still taken from a video posted to social media by Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka.

items.synopsis: In a social media announcement, the prime minister appeared in front of the camera with a dressing on his head and a business shirt still spattered lightly with blood.

title.children: Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka delays China visit after head injury

image.altText: Portrait of Veronica Corstorphine, who was allegedly murdered in Launceston

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian court dismisses an appeal by a woman who suffocated her mother with a pillow in 2019 — with one judge dissenting, saying the evidence from one expert "fatally infected" the fairness of the trial.

title.children: Woman who suffocated mother with pillow in 2019 loses appeal

image.altText: An Australian swimmer punches the air with her right hand after winning a world championship final race..

items.synopsis: Kaylee McKeown seals her place as the queen of the 100m backstroke, claiming Australia's fifth gold of the World Aquatics Championships in Japan.

title.children: Kaylee McKeown wins women's 100 backstroke world title in Japan

image.altText: A young boy and girl wearing cowboy gear smile at eachother

title.children: Grit, guts and a devoted mum: What it takes to be one of Australia's youngest cowboys
